{{Infobox swimmer | name = Rostyslav Svanidze | image = <!-- Only free-content images are allowed for depicting living people -- see [[WP:NONFREE]]. --> | image_size = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels --> | caption = | fullname = Rostyslav Albertovych Svanidze | nicknames = | national_team = {{UKR}} | strokes = [[Freestyle swimming|Freestyle]] | club = Ukraïna Zaporizhzhia<ref name=rsva-death/> | coach = Ivan Proskura<ref name=rsva-death/> | collegeteam = | birth_date = {{birth date|1971|11|5|df=yes}} | birth_place =[[Tbilisi]], [[Georgian SSR]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2002|10|14|1971|11|5|df=yes}}<ref name=rsva-death/> | death_place = [[Zaporizhia]], [[Ukraine]] | height = {{convert|1.94|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|85|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} | medaltemplates = | show-medals = yes | updated = }}
'''Rostyslav Albertovych Svanidze''' ({{lang-uk|Ростислав Альбертович Сванідзе}}; November 5, 1971{{spaced ndash}}October 14, 2002) was a Ukrainian swimmer of Georgian descent, who specialized in middle-distance freestyle events.<ref>{{cite sports-reference|Rostyslav Svanidze|https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/sv/rostyslav-svanidze-1.html|27 May 2013}}</ref> He was a two-time Olympian (1996 and 2000), and a top 16 finalist in the 100 m freestyle at his Olympic debut in [[Atlanta]] (1996). As a member of Ukraine's senior national team, Svanidze had won a total of 37 swimming titles in middle-distance freestyle (100 and 200 m), and in freestyle relays (400 and 800 m). Although he never received a single medal in any international tournament, Svanidze was regarded as one of Ukraine's top swimmers in the post-independence era since the break-up of the [[Soviet Union]]. Before his untimely death in 2002, he worked as a senior lecturer under the faculty of physical education in [[Zaporizhia State Medical University]].
==Swimming career==
===Early years=== Svanidze, a native in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgian SSR]], started his sporting career at the age of nine. He later became a pupil and a member of the swimming team for Ukraïna Zaporizhzhia, one of Ukraine's top sports clubs, under his longtime coach and mentor Ivan Proskura.<ref name=rsva-death/>
In 1995, Svanidze made his worldwide breakthrough at the [[1995 FINA World Swimming Championships (25 m)|FINA Short Course World Championships]] in [[Rio de Janeiro, Brazil]], where he placed fifth in a freestyle double (100 and 200 m). He also established a new Ukrainian record of 1:48.73 in the 200 m freestyle.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hawrylyshyn|first=George|title=On the road to Atlanta: Ukraine's swimmers take silver medals in Rio|url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/1995/519520.shtml|publisher=[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]|date=19–20 May 1995|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
Svanidze became one of the first ever swimmers to attend Ukraine's historic debut at the [[1996 Summer Olympics]] in [[Atlanta]] since the post-Soviet era. In the [[Swimming at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre freestyle|100 m freestyle]], he powered home with a fourteenth-place effort in the B-Final at 50.43, edging out Canada's [[Stephen Clarke (swimmer)|Stephen Clarke]] in a close finish by two-hundredths of a second (0.02).<ref>{{cite web|title=Atlanta 1996: Aquatics (Swimming) – Men's 100m Freestyle Final B |url=http://la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v3p1.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |work=[[Atlanta 1996]] |publisher=[[LA84 Foundation]] |page=36 |accessdate=28 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523164915/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v3p1.pdf |archivedate=23 May 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Team Ukraine at XXVI Summer Olympics|url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/archive/1996/30.pdf|format=[[PDF]]|edition=30|page=10|publisher=[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]|date=28 July 1996|accessdate=25 May 2013}}</ref>
===2000 Summer Olympics=== {{see also|Swimming at the 2000 Summer Olympics}}
At the [[2000 Summer Olympics]] in [[Sydney]], Svanidze competed in three swimming events, including two freestyle relays. He posted a [[FINA]] B-standard entry time of 1:52.34 (200 m freestyle) from the [[2000 European Aquatics Championships|European Championships]] in [[Helsinki, Finland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Swimming – Men's 200m Freestyle Startlist (Heat 4)|url=http://www.omegatiming.com/File/Download?id=000100060006000000FFFFFFFFFFFF00|format=[[PDF]]|work=[[Sydney 2000]]|publisher=Omega Timing|accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2000 LEN European Aquatics Championships (Helsinki, Finland) – Men's 200m Freestyle Heats|url=http://www.omegatiming.com/File/Download?id=000100090031000000FFFFFFFFFFFF01|format=[[PDF]]|publisher=Omega Timing|accessdate=27 April 2013}}</ref> On the first day of the Games, Svanidze teamed up with [[Vyacheslav Shyrshov]], [[Pavlo Khnykin]], and [[Artem Honcharenko]] in the [[Swimming at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 100 metre freestyle relay|4×100 m freestyle relay]]. Svanidze swam the second leg in heat three and recorded a split of 51.69, but the Ukrainians finished the race in fourth place and twelfth overall with a final time of 3:21.48.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sydney 2000: Swimming – Men's 4×100m Freestyle Relay Heat 3 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/Masters/sw/SWresults.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |work=[[Sydney 2000]] |publisher=[[LA84 Foundation]] |page=336 |accessdate=23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819181023/http://la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/Masters/sw/SWresults.pdf |archivedate=19 August 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Newberry|first=Paul|title=Thompson anchors U.S. relay win; Thorpe wins 400 free|url=http://www.canoe.ca/2000GamesSwimming/sep16_tho.html|publisher=[[Canoe.ca]]|date=16 September 2000|accessdate=28 May 2013}}</ref> In the [[Swimming at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metre freestyle|200 m freestyle]], Svanidze placed twenty-fourth on the morning prelims. Swimming in heat four, he picked up a second spot by almost a third of a second (0.33) behind winner [[Arūnas Savickas]] of Lithuania, in a time of 1:52.35.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sydney 2000: Swimming – Men's 200m Freestyle Heat 4 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/Masters/sw/SWresults.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |work=[[Sydney 2000]] |publisher=[[LA84 Foundation]] |page=125 |accessdate=23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819181023/http://la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/Masters/sw/SWresults.pdf |archivedate=19 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> Two days later, Svanidze, along with Goncharenko, [[Ihor Snitko]], and [[Serhiy Fesenko]], placed fourteenth in the [[Swimming at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 200 metre freestyle relay|4×200 m freestyle relay]] with a time of 7:32.16.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sydney 2000: Swimming – Men's 4×200m Freestyle Relay Heat 2 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/Masters/sw/SWresults.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |work=[[Sydney 2000]] |publisher=[[LA84 Foundation]] |page=341 |accessdate=23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819181023/http://la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/Masters/sw/SWresults.pdf |archivedate=19 August 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wide-open race in the men's 100 free|url=http://www.canoe.ca/2000GamesSwimming/sep19_wid.html|publisher=[[Canoe.ca]]|date=18 September 2000|accessdate=26 May 2013}}</ref>
Shortly after his second Olympics, Svanidze announced his retirement from swimming. He worked as a full-time senior lecturer under the faculty of [[physical education]], [[social pedagogy]], and [[psychology]] at the [[Zaporizhia State Medical University]] in [[Zaporizhia]].<ref name=rsva-death>{{cite news|script-title=uk:Заслуженный тренер украины по плаванию иван проскура: "за три дня до смерти моего ученика ростика сванидзе девушке, которая тренировалась с ним в одном бассейне, приснился сон, будто он умер"|trans-title=Honored coach of Ukraine's Swimming Team Ivan Proskura, "Three days before the death of my student Rostislav Svanidze, a girl who trained with him in the same pool had a dream that he died"|language=Ukrainian|url=http://fakty.ua/83143-zasluzhennyj-trener-ukrainy-po-plavaniyu-ivan-proskura-quot-za-tri-dnya-do-smerti-moego-uchenika-rostika-svanidze-devushke-kotoraya-trenirovalas-s-nim-v-odnom-bassejne-prisnilsya-son-budto-on-umer-quot|publisher=[[Fakty i Kommentarii]]|date=19 October 2002|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
==Death== On October 16, 2002, just three weeks before his thirty-first birthday, Svanidze was found unconscious inside the gymnasium at [[Zaporizhia State Medical University]] after having suffered a [[cardiac arrest]]. He started to become ill while conducting an evening training session for students. He responded to them: "I have a headache; train? probably not; Go to class time, my fellow students". While proceeding to the university's gymnasium, Svanidze felt bad, and eventually collapsed.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В Запорожье прошли похороны известного украинского пловца Ростичлава Сванидзе|trans-title=In Kiev was the funeral of the famous Ukrainian swimmer Rostyslav Svanidze|language=Russian|url=http://ria.ru/sport/20021016/244365.html|publisher=[[Fakty i Kommentarii]]|date=19 October 2002|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref> He was found unconscious by one of his students, before being brought to the University's hospital. Eleven minutes later, he was pronounced dead. Doctors discovered that Svanidze had suffered a [[cerebral hemorrhage]], caused by a [[traumatic aortic rupture]], at the time of his death.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=uk:31-летний украинский пловец ростислав сванидзе умер от разрыва аорты, а американский боец даглас дейдж погиб прямо на ринге киевского дворца спорта|trans-title=31-year-old Ukrainian swimmer Rostyslav Svanidze died of aortic rupture, and an American wrestler Douglas Deydzh was killed directly on the ring of the Kiev Palace of Sports|language=Ukrainian|url=http://fakty.ua/79254-31-letnij-ukrainskij-plovec-rostislav-svanidze-umer-ot-razryva-aorty-a-amerikanskij-boec-daglas-dejdzh-pogib-pryamo-na-ringe-kievskogo-dvorca-sporta|publisher=[[Fakty i Kommentarii]]|date=4 July 2003|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
Svanidze's untimely death shocked the nation's entire swimming field. Olympic medalist [[Denys Sylantyev]] recalled his emotion for a posthumous swimmer: "It feels like Rostislav just left. Somewhere far away. He and I have never competed, but we were very good friends. In matters of sport, I did not consult with him, because it is impossible to swim in different distances. None of us sought advice in real-life situations, but there is no request that he had not fulfilled. If you cannot do something, It is no longer a promise. We spent a lot of time in training camp, and more often, made fun of each other." <ref name=rsva-death/>

{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=SS Clifton.jpg|100px |Ship caption=SS ''Clifton'', without self-unloading gear }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United States |Ship flag={{USN flag|1924}} |Ship name=''Clifton'' |Ship namesake=[[Samuel Mather]] |Ship owner=Progress Steamship company, Cleveland, a subsidiary of [[Cleveland-Cliffs, Inc.]] |Ship operator= |Ship registry=[[Cleveland, Ohio]] |Ship route= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[American Steel Barge Company]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=[[Superior, Wisconsin|West Superior, Wisconsin]] |Ship launched=1892 |Ship completed=1892 |Ship christened= |Ship acquired= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship identification= |Ship fate=Sank near [[Thunder Bay Island]] September 21–22, 1924, after encountering a large wave in [[gale]] |Ship status= |Ship notes=''Prior owner'' [[Pickands Mather Group|Pickands, Mather & Company]] ''Refit'' 1923–1924 to include installation of topside self-unloading gear}} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=[[Whaleback]] freighter |Ship tonnage= [[Gross Register Tonnage]] [[Net Register Tonnage]] |Ship length={{convert|308|ft|m|lk=on|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|30|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draught= |Ship draft= |Ship depth={{convert|24|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=Steam, [[propeller]] |Ship speed= |Ship capacity=3500 Tons |Ship crew=26 |Ship notes=Sank with loss of captain and 25 crew }} |} '''SS ''Clifton''''', originally ''Samuel Mather'', was a [[whaleback]] lake freighter built in 1892 for service on the [[Great Lakes]]. She was {{convert|308|foot}} long, {{convert|30|foot}} beam, and {{convert|24|foot}} depth, and had a 3,500 ton capacity. The self-propelled barge was built by the [[American Steel Barge Company]] in [[Superior, Wisconsin|West Superior, Wisconsin]]. Her builders used a [[naval architecture|design]] well-suited to carry iron ore, her intended trade. The new vessel was christened ''Samuel Mather'', after [[Samuel Mather|a cofounder]] of [[Pickands Mather Group|Pickands Mather and Company]], which at the time was the [[List of Pickands Mather ships|second largest fleet on the Great Lakes]]. After 31 years of service as an ore boat, the vessel was superannuated out of iron ore and was refitted as a carrier of [[Construction aggregate|stone aggregate]]. Her 1923–1924 refitting included the installation of topside self-unloading gear. The Smith-patented tunnel scrapers were intended to enable the ship to unload more quickly and to partially offload at ports that could not previously be serviced by ship.{{sfn|Brehm|2004|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3Z6H8QIk_6wC&pg=PA167 167–174]}} En route between [[Sturgeon Bay, Wisconsin|Sturgeon Bay]] and [[Detroit]] on the night of September 21–22, 1924, while loaded with crushed stone, she encountered a storm and sank off [[Lake Huron]]'s [[Thunder Bay Island]] with the loss of Captain Emmett Gallagher and the crew.{{efn-ua|Some sources say that there were 28 crew, but the contemporaneous listing was 26.{{sfn|Boyer|1968|pages=40–58}}}} According to one historian, ''Clifton'' became a "ghost ship of the Great Lakes",{{sfn|Boyer|1968|pages=40–58}} as there were no survivors and the events immediately leading up to the disaster were not known. The vessel's wreck was discovered on the bed of Lake Huron by [[technical diving|technical divers]] in September 2016, with the discovery confirmed by further dives and research in 2017. When the lost vessel was rediscovered, it was found that a poetic folk [[ballad]], written before 1932 by an Irish-American neighbor of the lost captain, contained a relatively accurate description of the ship's foundering.{{sfn|Walton|Grimm|2002|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=aBiPDKrvyKwC 180–181]}} ==History== [[File:Clifton.png|thumb|left|Launching the ''Clifton'']] ===Construction and service=== The ''Clifton'' was built by the American Steel Barge Co. and launched in 1892.{{sfn|Devendorf|1996|page=80}} Designed by [[Alexander McDougall (ship designer)|Captain Alexander McDougall]], whalebacks had a unique form. Their unusual design included a hull that curved, which when fully loaded resembled a whale's back. They were the precursors of the [[turret deck ship]] of the late 19th and early 20th century,{{sfn|Woodman|2002|page=179}} which like the whaleback had rounded hulls, but unlike the whaleback had conventional bows and sterns and a superstructure. A total of 44 whaleback vessels were constructed from 1887 to 1898, with most operating in the Great Lakes.{{sfn|Thompson|1994|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=irtD2o_uQ88C 47–51]}}{{efn-ua|[[SS Charles W. Wetmore|''Charles W. Wetmore'']] was the first to leave the lakes in June, 1891, sailing to London and from there to the west coast of the United States, where it was lost.{{cite web |url=http://www.boatnerd.com/news/archive/6-04.htm |work=Great Lakes & Seaway Shipping News Archive |title=Today in Great Lakes History June 30 |accessdate=February 8, 2008 |deadurl=yes |publisher=Boatnerd |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070805120508/http://www.boatnerd.com/news/archive/6-04.htm |archivedate=August 5, 2007 |df= }} [[SS City of Everett|''City of Everett'']] was an important whaleback steamship. It was constructed in the [[State of Washington]], sailed from 1894 until 1923, and was the first U.S. steamship to pass through the [[Suez Canal]] as well as the first to circumnavigate the globe.{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa4442/is_200410/ai_n16065472/pg_2 | work=Sea Classics | title=Last of the Whalebacks | year=2004}}}}[[File:Clifton2.png|thumb|left|The ''Clifton'' in dry dock]] As [[SS Samuel Mather|''Samuel Mather'']], she was the second of seven U.S. merchant ships to bear that name.{{sfn|Stonehouse|1998|pages=61–63}} The eponymously-named ''Mather'', a/k/a ''Clifton'', was built at the personal expense of [[Samuel Mather]], a cofounder of [[Pickands Mather Group|Pickands Mather and Company]]. For the better part of the twentieth century's first two decades, the company operated the second largest shipping fleet on the Great Lakes.{{cite report|last=Brock|first=S.G.|title=Report of the Internal Commerce of the United States for the Year 1891. Ex. Doc. 6, Part 2. U.S. House of Representatives. 52d Cong., 1st sess|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=U.S. Government Printing |date=1892|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ipI3AQAAIAAJ|pages=48–40}} After sailing for 31 years, she was deemed superannuated. The ship would no longer transport iron ore, and instead was retrofitted as a carrier of stone aggregate. This 1923–1924 refit included the installation of topside self-unloading gear, which affected her [[center of gravity]] and [[righting moment]].{{sfn|Boyer|1968|pages=40–58}} As wreck discoverer David Trotter stated: "We found that the self-unloading mechanism was still in position, and that was an interesting discovery because we now realize that the unloading mechanism didn’t break free, causing the Clifton to have instability, resulting in her sinking." The self-unloading machinery "was added the same year she disappeared," responded maritime expert Valerie Van Heest.{{efn-ua|Valerie van Heest is a member of the [[Michigan Shipwreck Research Associates|Michigan Shipwreck Research Association's]] board of directors. The nonprofit group is instrumental in preserving and interpreting Michigan's maritime history.}} She said the discovery has many levels of significance. She said, "All of it was additional weight above the center line of the vessel", and that it was not coincidental that three other ships outfitted with an identical self-unloading system all sank.{{efn-ua|[[SS Andaste|''Andaste'']] was retrofitted with a self loader and lost on 9 September 1929 in [[Lake Michigan]] with all hands. A similar retrofit and sinking involved the ''[[Hennepin (shipwreck)|Hennepin]]''}}{{cite web|url=http://www.michiganshipwrecks.org/hennepin.htm |title=MSRA – The wreck of the Hennepin |publisher=[[Michigan Shipwreck Research Associates]] |accessdate=February 24, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212073258/http://www.michiganshipwrecks.org/hennepin.htm |archivedate=February 12, 2008 |df= }} Four of the refitted ships were lost in relatively quick progression.{{sfn|Brehm|2004|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3Z6H8QIk_6wC&pg=PA174 174]}} ==Sinking== ===Loss=== At the time of her loss, ''Clifton'' was owned by the Progress Steamship Co. of Cleveland,{{cite news|title=Lake Hides Secret of Lost Boat|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=September 26, 1924|page=1}}{{cite news |author= |title=Institute Search for Missing Freight Vessel |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14567447/ |work=Dixon Evening Telegraph |page=1 |location=Dixon, Illinois |date=September 25, 1924 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} a subsidiary of [[Cleveland-Cliffs, Inc.]]{{sfn|Reynolds|Dawson|2011|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=GoXNi5gkTOgC 109]}} In ''Clifton''{{'}}s last position report as of 10:20 a.m. on September 21, 1924, it was entering Lake Huron near [[Mackinaw City]] approximately {{convert|100|miles}} from where it ultimately foundered.{{cite news |author= |title=Hope for Clifton is abandoned |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14568649/ |work=[[Hamilton Evening Journal]] |page=1 |location=Hamilton, Ohio |date=September 26, 1924 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} As the gravel boat tried to make its way down Lake Huron toward its scheduled destination in Detroit on the night of September 21–22, a "great storm swept [Lake] Huron".{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14572169/the_scranton_republican/ |newspaper=[[The Scranton Republican]] |title=Lake Whaleback With 28 Members of Crew Has Gone to Bottom |date=September 29, 1924 |page=1 |via=Newspapers.com {{open access}} |location=Scranton, Pennsylvania}} In the opinion of an experienced skipper who had worked his way through the gale, no vessel of ''Clifton'''s size could have survived in those conditions if she was {{convert|40|miles}} out to sea. Wreckage was widely scattered. Painted sticks of wreckage from the ''Clifton'' were recovered by ''Peter White'' on September 26, 1924, {{convert|24|miles}} northeast of [[Pointe aux Barques Light]],{{cite news |author= |title=Painted Sticks of wood possibly part of the whaleback Clifton |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14569013/ |work=[[Oshkosh Northwestern|The Oshkosh Northwestern]] |page=1|location=Oshkosh, Wisconsin |date=September 27, 1924 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14570503/ |title=Stick May Tell Fate of Clifton |via=Newspapers.com {{open access}}|newspaper=[[The Daily Tribune]] |location=Wisconsin Rapids, Wisconsin |date=September 27, 1924 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |page=1 {{open access}}}} and a life raft was found on October 1, 1924.{{cite news |author= |title=Find Life Raft of Clifton |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14568068/ |work=[[Chillicothe Constitution-Tribune|The Chillicothe Constitution-Tribune]] |page=2 |location=Chillicothe, Missouri |date=October 2, 1924 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}{{cite news |url=http://www.newser.com/story/249007/great-mystery-of-the-great-lakes-is-solved.html |title=Great Mystery of the Great Lakes Is Solved: SS Clifton found 100 miles south of last known location in Lake Huron |first1=Arden |last1=Dier |publisher=[[Newser]] |date=September 22, 2017 |accessdate=October 21, 2017}} On the [[Detour Township, Michigan|Detour, Michigan]]–[[Goderich, Ontario]] course, about {{convert|70|mi}} away from the latter, hatch covers, and the forward end of a [[pilot house]] (with [[searchlight]] and clock attached) were recovered by the S.S. ''Glencairn''. The clock had stopped at 4:00, which is hypothesized to have been 4:00 a.m. on September 22, when storm waters on Lake Huron were at their height.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14570548/ |title=Ship Wreckage Found in Lake |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Oneonta)|The Oneonta Star]] |location=Oneonta, New York |date=September 1924 |page=1|via=Newspapers.com {{open access}}7}}{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14571867/the_bridgeport_telegram/ |newspaper=[[The Bridgeport Telegram]] |title=Abandon Hope for Missing Freighter, Find Wreckage |date=September 29, 1924 |page=1 |via=Newspapers.com {{open access}} |location=Bridgeport, Connecticut}}{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14569668/ |title=Wreckage From Lost Ship Found: No Trace of 28 [sic] Men Who Were Aboard Clifton in Lake Huron |newspaper=[[The Plain Dealer|The McHenry Plaindealer]] |date=October 2, 1924 |location=McHenry, Illinois |page=8 |via=Newspapers.com{{open access}}}} A cabin door was found in the vicinity of [[Thunder Bay (Michigan)|Thunder Bay]].{{efn-ua|The locale where the wreck was ultimately located.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14570357/ |title=Searchers Pick Up Cabin Door of Ill-Fated Clifton Off Thunder Bay, Report Says |newspaper=[[The Escanaba Daily Press]] |location=Escanaba, Michigan |date=September 30, 1924 |page=1 |agency=Associated Press |via=Newspapers.com {{open access}}|accessdate=October 22, 2017}}}} [[United States Army Air Service]] airplanes were dispatched from [[Mount Clemens, Michigan]], to conduct a search in [[Saginaw Bay]] in the vicinity of [[Tawas City, Michigan]].{{efn-ua|Presumably from [[Selfridge Air National Guard Base|Selfridge Air Base]], which is the only air base near Mount Clemens.}} Debris started washing up on the Canadian shore. No bodies were recovered, implying that the sinking was quick without deployment of [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboats]]. No mechanical malfunction has yet been discovered or any other definite cause of her sinking. Speculation at the time, which continued to be published decades after the tragedy, was that the newly-installed self-unloading gear could have broken free and contributed to the vessel's metacentric instability.{{sfn|Boyer|1968|pages=40–58}} However, after the discovery of the wreck it is now theorized that the vessel was overwhelmed by a wave or waves that drove it under power to the bottom. The obliteration of the first {{convert|40|feet}} of the bow is testament to the blunt force the ship endured. "The bow of the Clifton sustained heavy damage", said Trotter, after having seen footage shot by the divers. “The first 40 feet of the bow section is completely destroyed, likely caused by the impact with the lake’s bottom when she sank." ===Lament=== Three of the men lost with the ship, including captain Emmett Gallagher, were from the maritime community of [[St. James Township, Michigan|Beaver Island, Michigan]]. The island community, which at the time was predominantly Irish-American, maintained the tradition of generating a [[Folk music|folk-song]] [[lament]] for persons who were seen as having laid down their lives with heroism, and a ballad was written in honor of Captain Gallagher and the crew of ''Clifton''.{{sfn|Walton|Grimm|2002|pages=[https://books.google.com/books/about/Windjammers.html?id=aBiPDKrvyKwC 180–181]}} Attributed to islander Frank McCauley and collected by a folklore researcher in 1932, "The Seaman's Lament" purports to tell the story of the lost captain and crew. Lines 23 through 26 of the lament are of particular interest, as they set forth a hypothesis that the doomed vessel was slewed by a series of waves, an action equivalent to [[Broach (sailing)|broaching]] on a sailing ship. Once slewed, the cargo vessel was swamped and then foundered.{{sfn|Walton|Grimm|2002|pages=[https://books.google.com/books/about/Windjammers.html?id=aBiPDKrvyKwC 180–181]}}
And the mad billows leap like wild beasts from their lair, And in their wild rush not a life will they spare! And as they roll on over that structure of steel, The steamer does tremble from foretop to keel.
These lines proved to be significant when the vessel was found, as they matched the physical condition of the hull on the lake bottom. ===Discovery=== Ever since the 1924 sinking, the wreck was considered an ultimate goal for wreck hunters, partly because of its confounding disappearance, and partly because it was the only remaining whaleback to have sunk in Lake Huron and not be found. Exacerbating the problem was the sheer size of Lake Huron and potential ship gravesites. The lake has about {{convert|25000|sqmi}} with over {{convert|9000|sqmi}} on the United States side. The data on potential sites was obscure and very oblique, leaving widely scattered possibilities. David Trotter, a shipwreck author, discoverer, deep diver, and [[Maritime archaeology|maritime archeologist]], told the press that the lost vessel had been on his "bucket list", ranking close to #1 among non-found Great Lakes shipwrecks.{{efn-ua|Trotter offered that only finding ''[[Le Griffon]],'' a ship lost in 1679, could be better.}} At the time of the discovery, Trotter had found over 60 previously undiscovered wrecks while diving over the last 40 years. Some of his discoveries include sidewheel steamer ''Keystone State'' (1861 sinking with all hands); four-masted schooner, [[Minnedosa (schooner barge)|''Minnedosa'']] (1905 with all hands); and the {{convert|436|ft|m|adj=on}} [[SS Hydrus|''Hydrus'']], lost with all hands in the [[Great Storm of 1913|1913 Great Storm on Lake Huron]]. Trotter started his search for ''Clifton'' in 1987. Almost 30 years later, in June 2016, he and his team logged the coordinates of an unknown wreck. He stated that they had been working on a project that involved two other wrecks. The team dived the unknown lost vessel in September 2016, and when the diver surfaced, he reported to Trotter that the unidentified vessel was "a whaleback". Trotter instantly told his crew that they might well have discovered ''Clifton'', as it was the only as-yet-undiscovered whaleback to have been lost on Lake Huron. The senior diver wanted additional confirmation of this discovery before making it public. After deputizing several team members with [[action camera]]s, it was clear that the wreck was indeed a whaleback and was therefore ''Clifton''. Trotter's divers further explored and video-documented the wreck, making nine dives in July–August 2017. Careful work was necessary, as the long-lost hull had been found approximately 100 miles (160 km) from where she had been last seen and was believed to have sunk. Trotter made the identification public in September 2017.{{cite news |url=http://www.wzzm13.com/news/local/michigan-life/mystery-solved-ss-clifton-discovered-in-lake-huron/477353651 |title=MYSTERY SOLVED: ‘S.S. Clifton' discovered in Lake Huron |publisher=[[WZZM]] |first1=Brent |last1=Ashcroft |type=Video |accessdate=October 20, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/michigan/2017/09/22/freighter-missing-lake-huron-since-1924-found/692360001/ |title=Freighter missing in Lake Huron since 1924 found |first1=Charles E. |last1=Ramirez |newspaper=[[The Detroit News]] |date=September 22, 2017 |accessdate=October 20, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2017/09/21/clifton-discovered-lake-huron/691889001/ |date=September 21, 2017 |title=Clifton Discovered in Lake Huron |newspaper=[[Detroit Free Press]] |accessdate=October 20, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2017/09/22/lake-huron-historic-sunken-ship/ |location=Canton, Michigan |publisher=[[WWJ-TV]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |title=Deep Diver Discovers Historic Sunken Ship In Lake Huron |date=September 22, 2017 |accessdate=October 20, 2017}} The delay made it possible for the news to be formally released on September 21, 2017, the 93rd anniversary of the vessel's last surface sighting. Trotter said that the discovery was "a personal milestone" in a quest that he was fortunate enough to complete within his lifetime. Trotter told the press that ''Clifton''{{`s}} propeller is intact and its rudder pointing straight. Both data points suggest the vessel was moving in a straight line when it sank. Now, "she lies heavily on her port side, [indicating] that she got caught broadside by a very large wave". These factors of the discovery tend to support the McCauley hypothesis of the sinking,{{sfn|Walton|Grimm|2002|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=aBiPDKrvyKwC 180–181]}} as opposed to speculation that the vessel's self-unloading gear had broken its rigging and was swinging from side to side.{{sfn|Boyer|1968|pages=40–58}} The hull rests at a 45-degree angle to the lake bottom, consistent with being broadsided by a large wave. ===Victims=== The 26 members of the lost crew, in rank order with home town as listed by the Progress Steamship company, Cleveland, owners of the boat: {{div col|colwidth=18em}} #EMMETT GALLAGHER, captain, St. James, Mich. #WALTER J. OLSON, deck hand, South Chicago, Ill. #BERNARD SODERSTROM, deck hand, Washburn, Wis. #GEORGE HUSACK, deck hand, Sturgeon Bay #STANLEY GUTH, deck hand, Sturgeon Bay {{div col end}} ==Legacy== The disaster has been memorialized by Frank McCauley's poetic lament.{{sfn|Walton|Grimm|2002|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=aBiPDKrvyKwC 180–181]}} In addition, marine historian and maritime artist Robert McGreevy{{cite news |url=http://www.lakeshoreguardian.com/site/news/450/Marine-Artist-Robert-McGreevy-Receives-Honor#.We35sdenG70 |title=Marine Artist Robert McGreevy Receives Honor |newspaper=The Lakeshore Guardian |date=March 2015 |accessdate=October 23, 2017}}{{sfn|Carroll|2010|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=dTa1ZrhZ6BIC&pg=PA323 323]}} rendered a drawing of the ''Clifton'' "fighting for her life" before she sank in the storm, and another of her resting on the bottom. The sinking has been likened to the losses of ''[[Edmund Fitzgerald]]'', [[SS Carl D. Bradley|''Carl D. Bradley'']], and [[SS Daniel J. Morrell|''Daniel J. Morrell'']]. [[Dwight Boyer]] discussed the 1882 foundering of the [[SS Asia|SS ''Asia'']], the 1924 vanishing of the [[whaleback]] SS Clifton with all hands, the 1927 disappearance of the package freighter [[SS Kamloops|SS ''Kamloops'']], and the 1929 foundering of the car ferry [[SS Milwaukee|SS ''Milwaukee'']], in ''Ghost Ships of the Great Lakes'' (1968),{{sfn|Boyer|1968|pages=40–58}} and retold an account of the 1975 disappearance of the [[SS Edmund Fitzgerald|SS ''Edmund Fitzgerald'']] in his last book, ''Ships and Men of the Great Lakes'' (1977).{{cite book|author=Jill B. page.title: Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Simon de Montfort, 5th Earl of Leicester}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{more footnotes|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox noble | name = Simon V de Montfort | title = [[Earl of Leicester]] | image = Simon Leicester.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Simon de Montfort, in a drawing of a stained glass window found at [[Chartres Cathedral]] | alt = | succession = | reign = 1239 – 4 August 1265 | reign-type = Title held | predecessor = [[Simon de Montfort, 5th Earl of Leicester|Simon de Montfort, 5th Earl]] | successor = None, title forfeit | spouse = [[Eleanor of England, Countess of Leicester|Eleanor of England]] | issue = {{Plainlist| * [[Henry de Montfort]] * [[Simon VI de Montfort]] * [[Amaury de Montfort, Canon of York]] * [[Guy de Montfort, Count of Nola]] * Joanna de Montfort * Richard de Montfort * [[Eleanor de Montfort|Eleanor, Princess of Wales]] }} | issue-link = #Descendants | issue-pipe = | full name = | native_name = | styles = | titles = | noble family = | house-type = | father = [[Simon de Montfort, 5th Earl of Leicester]] | mother = [[Alix de Montmorency]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{circa|1208|lk=yes}} | birth_place = [[Montfort-l'Amaury]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Treharne |date=1998-07-20 |first=R. |title=Simon de Montfort, earl of Leicester |url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Simon-de-Montfort-earl-of-Leicester |website=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |ref=harv }}</ref> | death_date = 4 August 1265 (aged about 57) | death_place = [[Battle of Evesham|Evesham]], [[Worcestershire]] | burial_date = | burial_place = [[Evesham Abbey]] | occupation = Soldier and statesman | memorials = }}
'''Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester''' ({{circa|1208}} – 4 August 1265), sometimes referred to as '''Simon V de Montfort''' <!--(also spelt Munford) -->to distinguish him from [[Simon de Montfort (disambiguation)|his namesake relatives]], was a nobleman of French origin and a member of the [[Peerage of England|English peerage]], who led the [[baron]]ial opposition to the rule of King [[Henry III of England]], culminating in the [[Second Barons' War]]. Following his initial victories over royal forces, he became ''[[de facto]]'' ruler of the country,<ref name=dnb>{{cite DNB |last=Norgate |first=K. |display=Montfort, Simon of, Earl of Leicester (1208?–1265) |volume=38 |wstitle=Montfort, Simon of (1208?-1265) |authorlink=Kate Norgate |ref=harv }}</ref> and played a major role in the constitutional development of England.
During his rule, Montfort called two famous parliaments. [[Oxford Parliament (1258)|The first]] stripped the King of unlimited authority, while [[Simon de Montfort's Parliament|the second]] included ordinary citizens from the towns.<ref name=dnb /> For this reason, Montfort is regarded today as one of the [[wikt:progenitor|progenitors]] of modern [[parliamentary democracy]].<ref name=Jobson2012/> As Earl of Leicester he expelled Jews from the city; as he became ruler of England he also cancelled debts owed to Jews through violent seizures of records. Events in London and Worcester, for instance, led to massacres.<ref name=massacres/><ref name=DelanyLondon>See Delaney (2002), p217-8 on London</ref> After a rule of just over a year, Montfort was killed by forces loyal to the King in the [[Battle of Evesham]].<ref name=dnb />
==Family== Montfort was a younger son of [[Simon de Montfort, 5th Earl of Leicester]], a French nobleman and crusader, and [[Alix de Montmorency]]. His paternal grandmother was Amicia de Beaumont, the senior co-heiress to the [[Earl of Leicester|Earldom of Leicester]] and a large [[estate (law)|estate]] owned by her brother [[Robert de Beaumont, 4th Earl of Leicester]], in England.
With the irrevocable loss of Normandy, [[John of England|King John]] refused to allow the elder Simon to succeed to the earldom of Leicester and instead placed the estates and title into the hands of Montfort senior's cousin [[Ranulf de Blondeville, 6th Earl of Chester|Ranulf, the Earl of Chester]]. The elder Simon had also acquired vast domains during the [[Albigensian Crusade]], but was killed during the [[Siege of Toulouse (1217–18)|Siege of Toulouse]] in 1218 and his eldest son [[Amaury VI of Montfort|Amaury]] was not able to retain them. When Amaury was rebuffed in his attempt to get the earldom back, he agreed to allow his younger brother Simon to claim it in return for all family possessions in France.
Simon arrived in England in 1229, with some education but no knowledge of English, and received a sympathetic hearing from King [[Henry III of England|Henry]], who was well-disposed towards foreigners speaking [[French language|French]], then the language of the English court. Henry was in no position to confront the powerful Earl of Chester, so Simon approached the older, childless man himself and convinced him to cede him the earldom. It would take another nine years before Henry formally invested him with the title Earl of Leicester.
== Life ==
=== Early life === [[File:Simon de Montfort bas-relief in the U.S. House of Representatives chamber.jpg|thumb|[[Relief]] of Simon de Montfort in the [[United States Capitol#House Chamber|Chamber]] of the [[United States House of Representatives]]]] As a younger son, Simon de Montfort attracted little public attention during his youth, and the date of birth remains unknown. He is first mentioned when his mother made a grant to him in 1217.<ref>{{cite book | title=Simon de Montfort | last=Maddicott | first=John Robert | page=4 | year=1994 | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge }}</ref> As a boy, Montfort accompanied his parents during his father's campaigns against the [[Cathars]]. He was with his mother at the [[Siege of Toulouse (1217–1218)|Siege of Toulouse]] in 1218, where his father died after being struck on the head by a stone pitched by a [[mangonel]]. In addition to [[Amaury VI of Montfort|Amaury]], Simon had another older brother, Guy, who was killed at the siege of [[Castelnaudary]] in 1220. As a young man, Montfort probably took part in the [[Albigensian Crusade]]s of the early 1220s. He and Amaury both took part in the [[Barons' Crusade]].
In 1229 the two surviving brothers (Amaury and Simon) came to an arrangement with King Henry whereby Simon gave up his rights in France and Amaury gave up his rights in England. Thus freed from any allegiance to the King of France, Montfort successfully petitioned for the English inheritance, which he received the next year, although he did not take full possession for several years, and did not win formal recognition as Earl of Leicester until February 1239.
Montfort became a favourite of King Henry III and even issued a charter as "Earl of Leicester" in 1236, despite having not yet been granted the title.<ref>Maddicott, p. 19.</ref>
In that same year Simon tried to persuade [[Joan, Countess of Flanders]] to marry him. The idea of an alliance between the rich [[County of Flanders]] and a close associate of Henry III of England did not sit well with the French crown. The French Queen Dowager [[Blanche of Castile]] convinced Joan to marry [[Thomas II of Savoy]] instead.
=== Royal marriage === [[File:Eleanor Plantagenet, Countess of Leicester.jpg|thumb|right|[[Eleanor of England, Countess of Leicester|Eleanor of England]], who married Montfort in 1238]] In January 1238, Montfort married [[Eleanor of England, Countess of Leicester|Eleanor of England]], daughter of King [[John of England|John]] and [[Isabella of Angoulême]] and sister of King [[Henry III of England|Henry III]]. While this marriage took place with the King's approval, the act itself was performed secretly and without consulting the great barons, as a marriage of such importance warranted. Eleanor had previously been married to [[William Marshal, 2nd Earl of Pembroke]], and she swore a vow of perpetual [[chastity]] upon his death, when she was sixteen, which she broke by marrying Montfort. The [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Edmund Rich]], condemned the marriage for this reason. The English nobles protested the marriage of the King's sister to a foreigner of modest rank. Most notably, the King's and Eleanor's brother [[Richard, 1st Earl of Cornwall]], rose up in revolt when he learned of the marriage. King Henry eventually bought off Richard with 6,000 marks and peace was restored.
The marriage brought the manor of [[Sutton Valence]] in [[Kent]] into Montfort's possession.<ref name=Valence>{{cite web |url=http://www.suttonvalence.org.uk/his/framehistsummary.html |title=The history of Sutton Valence and its buildings, History's hand on Sutton Valence |publisher=Sutton Valence Parish Council |first=David |last=Wilson |accessdate=3 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313225356/http://www.suttonvalence.org.uk/his/framehistsummary.html |archivedate=13 March 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Relations between King Henry and Montfort were cordial at first. Henry lent him his support when Montfort embarked for Rome in March 1238 to seek papal approval for his marriage. When Simon and Eleanor's first son was born in November 1238 (despite rumours, more than nine months after the wedding), he was baptised Henry in honour of his royal uncle. In February 1239, Montfort was finally invested with the [[Earl of Leicester|Earldom of Leicester]]. He also acted as the king's counsellor and was one of the nine godfathers of Henry's eldest son, Prince Edward, who would inherit the throne and become [[Edward I of England|Edward I]] ("Longshanks").
===Expulsion of Jews from Leicester=== As Earl of [[Leicester]], Montfort expelled the small [[Jews|Jewish]] community from the city in 1231, banishing them "in my time or in the time of any of my heirs to the end of the world".<ref>Delany (2002), see page 48</ref> He justified his action as being "for the good of my soul, and for the souls of my ancestors and successors".<ref>Mundill (2002), p60</ref> His parents had shown a similar hostility to Jews in France, where his father was known for his devout Christianity, and his mother had given the Jews of [[Toulouse]]<ref>Maddicott, p5-6, describes his mother's Crusader militancy in Toulouse</ref> a choice of conversion or expulsion.<ref>Graetz (1891), p514</ref> [[Grosseteste]], then [[List of Archdeacons of Leicester|Archdeacon of Leicester]], may have prompted the expulsion{{citationneeded|reason=other sources appear to contradict this|date=May 2018}} however, Grosseteste appears to have been a restraining influence on the policy.<ref>Levy, S (1902), p38-39</ref> Expelling the Jews enhanced Montfort's popularity in his new domains because it removed the practice of [[usury]] (widely associated with Jews).<ref> Maddicott, p. 16.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Harris |first=Oliver |title=Jews, jurats and the Jewry Wall: a name in context |journal=Transactions of the Leicestershire Archaeological and Historical Society |volume=82 |year=2008 |pages=113–33 (128–33) |url=https://www.le.ac.uk/lahs/downloads/2008/2008%20(82)%20113-133%20Harris.pdf }}</ref>
Leicester's Jews were allowed to move to the eastern suburbs, which were controlled by Montfort's great-aunt [[Margaret, Countess of Winchester]], who had taken advice from [[Grosseteste]].<ref>Levy, S (1902), p38-39</ref> {{more|History of the Jews in England (1066–1290)#Increasing persecution, 13th century}}
=== Crusade and turning against the King === [[File:Leicester Clock Tower Simon de Montfort 2.jpg|thumb|right|Statue of Montfort on the [[Haymarket Memorial Clock Tower]] in [[Leicester]]]] Shortly after Prince Edward's birth, however, there was a falling out between the brothers-in-law. Simon owed a great sum of money to [[Thomas II of Savoy]], uncle of Queen Eleanor, and named King Henry as security for his repayment. The King evidently had not approved this, and was enraged when he discovered that Montfort had used his name. On 9 August 1239, Henry is reported to have confronted Montfort, called him an [[excommunication|excommunicant]] and threatened to imprison him in the [[Tower of London]]. "You seduced my sister", King Henry said, "and when I discovered this, I gave her to you, against my will, to avoid scandal." Simon and Eleanor fled to France to escape Henry's wrath.
Having announced his intention to go on [[crusade]] two years before, Simon raised funds and travelled to the [[Holy Land]] during the [[Barons' Crusade]], but does not seem to have faced combat there. He was part of the crusading host which, under [[Richard, 1st Earl of Cornwall|Richard of Cornwall]], negotiated the release of Christian prisoners including Simon's older brother [[Amaury VI of Montfort|Amaury]]. In autumn 1241, he left [[Syria]] and joined King Henry's campaign against King [[Louis IX of France|Louis IX]] in [[Poitou]]. The campaign was a failure, and an exasperated Montfort declared that Henry should be locked up like King [[Charles the Simple]]. Like his father, Simon was a soldier as well as a capable administrator. His dispute with King Henry came about due to the latter's determination to ignore the swelling discontent within the country, caused by a combination of factors, including famine and a sense among the English Barons that King Henry was too quick to dispense favour to his [[Poitiers|Poitevin]] relatives and [[Savoy]]ard in-laws.
In 1248, Montfort again took the cross with the idea of following [[Louis IX of France]] to [[Egypt]]. But, at the repeated requests of King Henry, he gave up this project in order to act as the king's [[lieutenant in the Duchy of Aquitaine]] (Gascony). Bitter complaints were excited by the rigour with which Montfort suppressed the excesses of the Seigneurs and of contending factions in the great communes. Henry yielded to the outcry and instituted a formal inquiry into Simon's administration. Simon was formally acquitted on the charges of oppression, but his accounts were disputed by Henry and Simon retired to France in 1252. The nobles of France offered him the Regency of the kingdom, vacated by the death of Queen [[Blanche of Castile]]. The earl preferred to make his peace with Henry III, which he did in 1253, in obedience to the exhortations of the dying [[Robert Grosseteste]], Bishop of Lincoln. He helped the King deal with disaffection in Gascony, but their reconciliation was a hollow one. In the Parliament of 1254, Simon led the opposition in resisting a royal demand for a subsidy. In 1256–57, when the discontent of all classes was coming to a head, Montfort nominally adhered to the royal cause. He undertook, with [[Peter II, Count of Savoy|Peter of Savoy]], the Queen's uncle, the difficult task of extricating the King from the pledges which he had given to the [[Pope]] with reference to the Crown of [[Sicily]]; and Henry's writs of this date mention Montfort in friendly terms. But at the "Mad Parliament" of [[Oxford Parliament (1258)|Oxford (1258)]] Montfort appeared with the [[Richard de Clare, 5th Earl of Hertford|Earl of Gloucester]],<ref>Blaauw, William Henry. (1871) ''The barons' war; including the battles of Lewes and Evesham.''[https://books.google.com/books?id=hUELAAAAYAAJ&ots=cmoZpyX0D3&dq=blaauw%2C%20william%20henry&pg=PP2#v=onepage&q&f=false] 2nd Ed.; Baxter and Son; p. 68. Google Book Search. Retrieved on 16 December 2010.</ref><ref name=EB1911/> at the head of the opposition. He was part of the [[Council of Fifteen]] who were to constitute the supreme board of control over the administration. The King's success in dividing the barons and in fostering a reaction, however, rendered such projects hopeless. In 1261, Henry revoked his assent to the [[Provisions of Oxford]] and Montfort, in despair, left the country.<ref name=EB1911/>
=== War against the King === {{Main article|Second Barons' War}} [[File:Site of the Battle of Lewes 1264 - geograph.org.uk - 71534.jpg|thumb|right|Site of the Battle of Lewes]] Simon de Montfort returned to England in 1263, at the invitation of the barons who were now convinced of the King's hostility to all reform and raised a rebellion with the avowed object of restoring the form of government which the Provisions had ordained.<ref name=EB1911/> Cancellation of debts (owed to Jews) was part of his call to arms.<ref>Mundill, 2002 p254 says "Simon de Montfort … used the cancellation of Jewish debts to his own advantage and had managed to convince followers that it was worth rebelling for."</ref>
These "cancellations" involved massacres of Jews by his followers to obtain their financial records, for instance in [[Worcester]]<ref>Mundill 2002, p42</ref> and [[London]].<ref name=DelanyLondon/> The Worcester attack and killings were led by de Montfort's son [[Henry de Montfort|Henry]] and [[Robert de Ferrers, 6th Earl of Derby|Robert Earl Ferrers]].<ref name=bhoworcester>'The city of Worcester: Introduction and borough', in A History of the County of Worcester: Volume 4, ed. William Page and J W Willis-Bund (London, 1924), pp. 376–390. British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/worcs/vol4/pp376-390 [accessed 20 May 2018].</ref> At London, one of his key followers John fitz John, led the attack and is said to have killed leading Jewish figures Isaac fil Aaron and Cok fil Abraham with his bare hands. He allegedly shared the loot with Montfort. 500 Jews died.<ref name=Mundill2010>Mundill (2010), p88-89</ref>
His son Simon led a further attack on Jews in [[Winchester]]. Jews in [[Canterbury]],<ref>Mundill (2002), p43</ref> were murdered or driven out in by a force led by [[Gilbert de Clare, 7th Earl of Gloucester|Gilbert de Clare]]<ref>Richard Huscroft, ''Expulsion: England's Jewish Solution'' (2006), p. 105.</ref><ref>Mundill (2002), p42</ref> There was further violence in [[Lincoln, England|Lincoln]], [[Cambridge]], Wilton<ref>Mundill (2002), p43</ref> and [[Northampton]].<ref name=Jacobs>Jacobs (1906)</ref><ref name=Mundill2010/>
Each attack was aimed at seizure of the records of debts, stored in locked chests within each community called 'archae'. Archae were legally mandated by the king for Jews to be allowed to conduct any business.<ref>{{cite web |title=Archae |url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/1727-archa |publisher=Jewish Enyclopedia}}</ref> They were destroyed or gathered for instance at [[Ely, Cambridgeshire|Ely]] by the rebels.<ref>Mundill (2010), p88-99</ref><ref name=Jacobs/>
Henry quickly gave in and allowed Montfort to take control of the council. His son [[Edward I of England|Edward]], however, began using patronage and bribes to win over many of the barons. Their disruption of parliament in October led to a renewal of hostilities, which saw the royalists able to trap Simon in London. With few other options available, Montfort agreed to allow [[Louis IX of France]] to arbitrate their dispute. Simon was prevented from presenting his case to Louis directly on account of a broken leg, but little suspected that the King of France, known for his innate sense of justice, would completely annul the Provisions in his [[Mise of Amiens]] in January 1264. Civil war broke out almost immediately, with the royalists again able to confine the reformist army in London. In early May 1264, Simon marched out to give battle to the King and scored a spectacular triumph at the [[Battle of Lewes]] on 14 May 1264, capturing the King, Prince Edward, and [[Richard of Cornwall]], Henry's brother and the titular King of Germany.
Montfort announced after the Battle of Lewes that all debts owed to the Jews were cancelled, as he had promised.<ref name=Jacobs/>
=== Rule and parliamentary reform === {{main|Simon de Montfort's Parliament}} Montfort used his victory to set up a government based on the provisions first established at Oxford in 1258. Henry retained the title and authority of King, but all decisions and approval now rested with his council, led by Montfort and subject to consultation with parliament. His Great Parliament of 1265 ([[Montfort's Parliament]]) was a packed assembly to be sure, but it can hardly be supposed that the representation which he granted to the towns was intended to be a temporary expedient.<ref name=EB1911/>
Montfort sent his summons, in the King's name, to each [[county]] and to a select list of [[borough]]s, asking each to send two representatives. This body was not the first elected [[Parliament of England|parliament]] in England. In 1254, Henry was in Gascony and in need of money. He gave instructions for his regent, Queen Eleanor, to summon a parliament consisting of knights elected by their shires to ask for this 'aid'. Montfort, who was in that parliament, took the innovation further by including ordinary citizens from the boroughs, also elected, and it was from this period that parliamentary representation derives. The list of boroughs which had the right to elect a member grew slowly over the centuries as monarchs granted charters to more English towns. (The last charter was given to Newark in 1674.)
The right to vote in Parliamentary elections for county constituencies was uniform throughout the country, related to land ownership. In the Boroughs, the electoral franchise varied and individual boroughs had varying arrangements.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}}
=== Fall from power and death === {{Main article|Battle of Evesham}} The reaction against Montfort's government was baronial rather than popular.<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911|title=Montfort, Simon de|inline=1}}</ref> The [[Welsh Marcher Lord]]s were friends and allies of Prince Edward, and when he escaped in May 1265, they rallied around his opposition. The final nail was the defection of [[Gilbert de Clare, 7th Earl of Gloucester|Gilbert de Clare, the Earl of Gloucester]], the most powerful baron and Simon's ally at Lewes. Clare had grown resentful of Simon's fame and growing power. When he and his brother Thomas fell out with Simon's sons [[Henry de Montfort|Henry]], [[Simon de Montfort, the younger|Simon]], and [[Guy de Montfort, Count of Nola|Guy]], they deserted the reforming cause and joined Edward.
Though boosted by Welsh infantry sent by Montfort's ally [[Llywelyn ap Gruffudd]], Simon's forces were severely depleted. Prince Edward attacked his cousin, his godfather's son Simon's forces at [[Kenilworth]], capturing more of Montfort's allies. Montfort himself had crossed the [[Severn]] with his army, intending to rendezvous with his son [[Simon de Montfort, the younger|Simon]]. When he saw an army approaching at [[Evesham]], Montfort initially thought it was his son's forces. It was, however, Edward's army flying the Montfort banners they had captured at Kenilworth. At that point, Simon realised he had been out-manoeuvred by Edward.
[[File:Montfort Evesham.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|right|A 13th-century cloth depiction of the mutilation of Montfort's body after the Battle of Evesham]] An ominous black cloud hung over the field of [[Evesham]] on 4 August 1265 as Montfort led his army in a desperate uphill charge against superior forces, described by one chronicler as the "murder of Evesham, for battle it was none".<ref>Robert of Gloucester, ''Chronicle'' translated by Stevenson, Rev. Joseph, ed. (1858) in ''The Church Historians of England: Prereformation series, Volume 5, Part 1''; Seeleys; p. 375.</ref> On hearing that his son Henry had been killed, Montfort replied, "Then it is time to die."<ref name=Sharma/> During the battle, a twelve-man squad of Edward's men had stalked the battlefield independent of Edward's main army, their sole aim being to find the earl and cut him down. Montfort was hemmed in; [[Roger Mortimer, 1st Baron Mortimer|Roger Mortimer]] killed Montfort by stabbing him in the neck with a lance.<ref name="Dan Jones p. 280">Dan Jones, "The Plantagenets: The Kings Who Made England" p. 280</ref> Montfort's last words were said to have been "Thank God".<ref name=Sharma>{{cite book|first=Simon|last=Sharma|title=A History of Britain|page=184|isbn=0-563-38497-2}}</ref> Also slain with Montfort were other leaders of his movement, including [[Peter de Montfort]] and [[Hugh le Despencer, 1st Baron le Despencer|Hugh Despenser]].
Montfort's body was mutilated in a frenzy by the royalists. News reached the mayor and sheriffs of London that "the head of the earl of Leicester ... was severed from his body, and his testicles cut off and hung on either side of his nose";<ref name="Dan Jones p. 280"/> and in such guise the head was sent to [[Wigmore Castle]] by [[Roger Mortimer, 1st Baron Mortimer]], as a gift to his wife, [[Maud de Braose, Baroness Mortimer|Maud]].<ref>Thomas B. Costain, ''The Magnificent Century'', p. 308</ref> His hands and feet were also cut off and sent to diverse places to enemies of his as a great mark of dishonour to the deceased.<ref>Dan Jones, "The Plantagenets: The Kings Who Made England" pp. 280–281</ref> Such remains as could be found were buried under the altar of [[Evesham Abbey]] by the canons. It was visited as holy ground by many commoners until King Henry caught wind of it. He declared that Montfort deserved no spot on holy ground and had his remains reburied under an insignificant tree. The remains of some of Montfort's soldiers who had fled the battlefield were found in the nearby village of [[Cleeve Prior]].
Montfort's niece, [[Margaret of England]], later killed one of the soldiers responsible for his death, purposely or inadvertently.
[[Matthew Paris]] reports that the [[Bishop of Lincoln]], [[Robert Grosseteste]], once said to Montfort's eldest son, Henry, "My beloved child, both you and your father will meet your deaths on one day, and by one kind of death, but it will be in the name of justice and truth."
==Legacy== In the years that followed his death, Simon de Montfort's grave was frequently visited by pilgrims. [[Napoleon|Napoleon Bonaparte]] described Simon de Montfort as "one of the greatest Englishmen".<ref>Napoleon Bonaparte, ''Napoleon's Notes on English History made on the Eve of the French Revolution, illustrated from Contemporary Historians and referenced from the findings of Later Research by Henry Foljambe Hall'' (New York: E. P. Dutton & Co., 1905), 12, 56.</ref> Today, Montfort is mostly remembered as one of the fathers of [[Representative democracy|representative government]].<ref name=Jobson2012>{{cite book|last1=Jobson|first1=Adrian|title=The First English Revolution: Simon de Montfort, Henry III and the Barons' War|date=2012|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=978-1-84725-226-5|pages=173–4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9gHWamp-TLoC&pg=PA174#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Simon de Montfort: The turning point for democracy that gets overlooked|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-30849472|accessdate=19 January 2015|publisher=BBC|date=19 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The January Parliament and how it defined Britain|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/11355822/The-January-Parliament-and-how-it-defined-Britain.html|accessdate=28 January 2015|publisher=The Telegraph|date=20 January 2015}}</ref>
Montfort bears responsibility for [[History_of_the_Jews_in_England_(1066–1290)#Increasing_persecution,_13th_century|persecution of Jews]]. In addition to his expulsion of Jews from Leicester, his faction in the Second Baron's War initiated pogroms killing perhaps the majority of Jews in Worcester and around 500 in London.<ref name=massacres>See Robin R. Mundill (2002), p9, p41, p60, p259, p265</ref><ref> Richmond, in Kushner (ed) 1992, see p47-48</ref> The violence and killings unleashed by the war targeting Jews carried on after his death.<ref>Hillaby (2013), p275</ref> [[Leicester City Council]] made a formal statement in 2001<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ww1.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2001&dt=0121&pub=Utusan_Express&sec=OddsEnds&pg=oe_07.htm|title=English city renounces 800-year ban on Jews|work=[[Utusan Malaysia]]|date=21 January 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7774455.Into_battle_to_defend_Simon_de_Montfort/|title=Into battle to defend Simon de Montfort|work=[[Worcester News]]|date=25 January 2001}}</ref> that "rebuked De Montfort for his blatant anti-Semitism".<ref>{{cite web|quote=Almost 800 years after his death, Leicester City Council formally rebuked Simon de Montfort for his blatant anti-Semitism|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/worldwars/genocide/forgive_01.shtml|title=Is Forgiveness Possible? A Jewish Perspective|authorlink1=Albert Friedlander|first1=Albert|last1=Friedlander|work=BBC History}}</ref>
[[File:De montfort evesham.jpg|thumb|right|Memorial stone on the site of Montfort's grave, Evesham]] [[Evesham Abbey]] and the site of Montfort's grave were destroyed with the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries]] in the 16th century. In 1965, a memorial of stone from [[Montfort-l'Amaury]] was laid on the site of the former altar by [[Speaker of the British House of Commons|Speaker of the House of Commons]] Sir [[Harry Hylton-Foster]] and [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Michael Ramsey]].
Various local honours were dedicated to his memory, and he has become eponymous several times over. [[De Montfort University]] in [[Leicester]] is named after him, as is the nearby [[De Montfort Hall]], a concert venue. A statue of Montfort is one of four to adorn the [[Haymarket Memorial Clock Tower]] in [[Leicester]]. A [[relief]] of Montfort adorns the wall of the [[United States Capitol#House Chamber|Chamber]] of the [[United States House of Representatives]].
Montfort's banner called the 'Arms of Honour of Hinckley', blazoned ''party per pale indented argent and gules'', and displayed in stained glass in [[Chartres Cathedral]], is especially used in the coat of arms of the town of [[Hinckley]], part of his Earldom in [[Leicestershire]], and by many of its local organizations. Combined with his personal Coat of Arms, the banner forms part of the club crest for the town's football club [[Hinckley A.F.C.]]<ref name="Hinckley United Independent Club Crest">{{Cite news |url=http://www.atleticohinckley.co.uk/feature/crest.html |title=Hinckley Independent Club Crest History |date=22 February 2014 |publisher=Hinckley Independent |accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
A school<ref>{{cite web | title=The de Montfort School, Evesham | url=http://www.tdms.worcs.sch.uk/ | accessdate=14 May 2007}}</ref> and a bridge on the north east stretch of the [[A46 road|A46]] are named after him in [[Evesham]].
==Descendants== Simon de Montfort and [[Eleanor of England, Countess of Leicester|Eleanor of England]] had seven children, many of whom were notable in their own right:<ref name=thepeerage>[http://thepeerage.com/p10152.htm#i101518 Record for ''Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester'' on ''www.thepeerage.com'']</ref> # [[Henry de Montfort]] (November 1238 – 1265) # [[Simon the Younger de Montfort]] (April 1240 – 1271) # [[Amaury de Montfort, Canon of York]] (1242/1243-1300) # [[Guy de Montfort, Count of Nola]] (1244–1288). [[Elizabeth Woodville]], Queen Consort of [[Edward IV of England]], was one of Guy's descendants through his daughter, [[Anastasia de Montfort, Countess of Nola]]. # Joanna de Montfort (born and died in Bordeaux between 1248 and 1251). # Richard de Montfort (d.1266). Date of death is not certain. # [[Eleanor de Montfort]] (1252–1282). She married [[Llywelyn ap Gruffudd]], [[Prince of Wales]], honouring an agreement that had been made between Earl Simon and Llywelyn. Eleanor, Lady of Wales, died on 19 June 1282 at the royal Welsh home at [[Abergwyngregyn]], on the north coast of Gwynedd, giving birth to a daughter, [[Gwenllian of Wales]]. After Llywelyn's death on 11 December 1282, Gwenllian was captured by King Edward I and spent the rest of her life in a convent.

[[Mentioned in Despatches]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] '''Sir William Robert Robertson, 1st Baronet''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCB|GCMG|GCVO|DSO}} (29 January 1860 – 12 February 1933) was a [[British Army]] officer who served as [[Chief of the General Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Imperial General Staff]] (CIGS) – the professional head of the British Army – from 1916 to 1918 during the [[First World War]]. As CIGS he was committed to a [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] strategy focusing on Germany and was against what he saw as peripheral operations on other fronts. While CIGS, Robertson had increasingly poor relations with [[David Lloyd George]], Secretary of State for War and then Prime Minister, and threatened resignation at Lloyd George's attempt to subordinate the British forces to the French Commander-in-Chief, [[Robert Nivelle]]. In 1917 Robertson supported the continuation of the Third Ypres Offensive, at odds with Lloyd George's view that Britain's war effort ought to be focused on the other theatres until the arrival of sufficient US troops on the Western Front. Robertson was the first and only British Army soldier to rise from [[Private (rank)|private soldier]] to field marshal.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/35786|title=‘Robertson, Sir William Robert, first baronet (1860–1933)’|subscription=yes|first=David R.|last=Woodward|date=September 2004|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/35786|accessdate=7 December 2007}} ==Early life== Robertson was born in [[Welbourn]], Lincolnshire, the son of Thomas Charles Robertson, a tailor and postmaster of Scottish ancestry, and Ann Dexter Robertson (née Beet).Bonham-Carter 1963, p1 He was educated at the local church school and as an older child earned 6d a week as a pupil-teacher. After leaving school in 1873 he became a garden boy in the village rectory, then in 1875 he became a footman in the [[Adeline, Countess of Cardigan and Lancastre|Countess of Cardigan]]'sshe was the widow of the infamous [[James Brudenell, 7th Earl of Cardigan|Lord Cardigan]] who had led the [[Charge of the Light Brigade]] household at [[Deene Park]]. He made no mention of this period in his life in his autobiography and seldom spoke of it, although during the First World War he is once said to have remarked to one of his aides: "Boy – I was a damn bad footman."Bonham-Carter 1963, p2-4 He began his military career in November 1877 by enlisting for twelve years as a [[Trooper (rank)|trooper]] in the [[16th The Queen's Lancers|16th (The Queen's) Lancers]].Woodward, 1998, p1 As he was three months short of the official minimum age of eighteen, at the behest of the recruiting sergeant he declared his age as eighteen years and two months, these extra five months becoming his "official" age throughout his time in the Army.Robertson 1921, p. 2 Heathcote p. 250 states that he was five months underage, which is not quite accurate His mother wrote to him in horror: "You know you are the Great Hope of the Family...if you do not like Service you can do something else...there are plenty of things Steady Young Men can do when they can write and read as you can...(the Army) is a refuge for all idle people...I shall name it to no one for I am ashamed to think of it...I would rather bury you than see you in a red coat."Bonham-Carter 1963, p5Mead, 2008, p53-4 On his first night in the Army he was so horrified by the rowdiness of the barrack room that he contemplated deserting, only to find that his civilian clothes, which had been parcelled up but not yet sent home, had already been stolen by another deserter.Holmes 2011, p548 As a young soldier Robertson was noted for his prowess at running, and for his voracious reading of military history. He won company first prizes for sword, lance and shooting. Among the young lieutenants under whom he served were future Lieutenant-General [[James Melville Babington|"Jimmy" Babington]] and "Freddy" Blair who would later be Robertson's Military Secretary at Eastern Command in 1918.Robertson 1921, p2 He was promoted to lance-corporal in February 1879 and corporal in April 1879. As a corporal he was imprisoned for three weeks with his head shaven when a soldier under arrest, whom he was escorting, escaped near [[London Waterloo station|Waterloo Station]]. Later, whilst serving in Ireland, he once kept soldiers under arrest handcuffed for a twelve-hour train journey rather than risk a repetition of the event.Bonham-Carter 1963, p28 He was promoted to lance-sergeant in May 1881, and sergeant in January 1882. He obtained a first class certificate of education in 1883, while serving in Ireland.Bonham-Carter 1963, p31 Robertson was promoted to [[Troop Sergeant Major|troop sergeant major]] in March 1885, to fill a vacancy as his predecessor, a former medical student serving in the ranks, had been demoted for making a botch of the regimental accounts and later committed suicide.Holmes 2011, p307 ==Junior officer== Encouraged by his officers, and the clergyman of his old parish,Woodward, 1998, p1Heathcote, p. 251 he passed an examination for an officer's commission and was posted as a [[second lieutenant]] in the [[3rd Dragoon Guards]] on 27 June 1888. Normally only four or five rankers were commissioned each year at that time.{{London Gazette|issue=25832|page=3498|date=26 June 1888}} Robertson later recorded that it would have been impossible to live as a cavalry [[subaltern]] in Britain, where £300 a year was needed in addition to the £120 official salary (approximately £30,000 and £12,000 at 2010 prices) to keep up the required lifestyle; he was reluctant to leave the cavalry,Mead, 2008, p52 but his Regiment was deployed to India, where pay was higher and expenses lower than in the UK. Robertson's father made his uniforms and he economised by drinking water with meals and not smoking, as pipes were not permitted in the mess and he could not afford the cigars which officers were expected to smoke. Robertson supplemented his income by studying with native tutors while others slept during the hot afternoons, qualifying as an interpreter—for which officers received cash grants—in [[Urdu]], [[Hindi]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Pashto]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]].Woodward, 1998, p2 [[File:Chitral 1895 by A D Gardyne.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A scene from the Chitral Expedition in 1895]] Promoted to [[Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)|lieutenant]] on 1 March 1891,{{London Gazette|issue=26170|page=3051|date=9 June 1891 |nolink=y}} he saw his first active service in 1891, distinguishing himself as Railway Transport Officer for the expedition to Kohat.Bonham-Carter 1963, pp34-5 He was appointed an [[attaché]] in the Intelligence Branch of the Quartermaster-General's Department at Simla in [[India]] on 5 June 1892.{{London Gazette|issue=26354|page=7399|date=16 December 1892 |nolink=y}} There he became a protégé of Sir [[Henry Brackenbury]], the new Military Member of the Viceroy's Council (i.e. equivalent to War Minister for India), who had been Director of Military Intelligence in London and was keen to beef up the intelligence branch of the Indian army, including mapping the [[Military history of the North-West Frontier|Northwest Frontier]]. Robertson spent a year writing a long and detailed "Gazetteer and Military Report on Afghanistan". After five years in India he was granted his first long leave in 1893, only to find that his mother had died before he reached home.Bonham-Carter 1963, p32 In June 1894 he undertook a three month journey via [[Gilgit]] and mountainous [[Kashmir and Jammu (princely state)|north Kashmir]], crossing the [[Darkot Pass]] at over 15,000 feet to reach the [[Pamir Mountains|Pamirs Plateau]] at the foot of the Himalayas, returning to India in August by a westerly route via [[Chilas]] and Khagan. On the journey he learned [[Gurkhali]] from a Gurkha, later qualifying in this, his sixth Indian language. He was promoted to [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] on 3 April 1895.{{London Gazette|issue=26612|page=1995|date=2 April 1895 |nolink=y}} He took part in the [[Chitral Expedition]] as Brigade Intelligence Officer to the force which marched through the [[Malakand Pass]] (he was present at the [[Siege of Malakand]] (3 April 1895)), across the [[Swat River]], via [[Dir, Pakistan|Dir]] to Chitral. He was described by Lieutenant-General [[Robert Low (Indian Army officer)|Sir Robert Low]], the Expedition Commander, as a "very active and intelligent officer of exceptional promise".Bonham-Carter 1963, pp35-8{{London Gazette|issue=26680|page=6176|date=15 November 1895 |nolink=y}} After the relief of [[Chitral Expedition|Chitral]] and installation of [[Shuja ul-Mulk|Shuja-ul-Mulk]] as Mehtar, Robertson was engaged in pacification and reconnaissance duties, but was wounded when attacked by his two guides on a narrow mountain path during a reconnaissance. One guide was armed with a shotgun and fired at Robertson but missed. The other guide attacked him with Robertson's own sword (which he had been carrying, as Robertson had dysentery) but Robertson punched him to the ground then drove off both attackers with his revolver; one was wounded and later captured and executed.{{cite web |url=http://www.nam.ac.uk/whats-on/lunchtime-lectures/video-archive/cleverest-man-army-life-fm-sir-william-robertson |title=Cleverest Man in the Army: The Life of FM Sir William Robertson |author=Saddington, Justin |date=12 December 2011 |work= |publisher=National Army Museum |accessdate=4 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117062048/http://www.nam.ac.uk/whats-on/lunchtime-lectures/video-archive/cleverest-man-army-life-fm-sir-william-robertson |archivedate=17 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }} The incident was reported and illustrated in the ''[[The Graphic|Daily Graphic]]'' and Robertson was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]],{{London Gazette|issue=26701|page=358|date=21 January 1896 |nolink=y}} which was, he later recorded, "then a rather rare decoration". ==Staff College== Robertson then applied to attend [[Staff College, Camberley|Staff College]] at [[Camberley]]. Unlike most applicants, he could not afford to take extended leave from his job (on the intelligence staff at [[Shimla|Simla]]) to attend a crammer, and had he failed he would have been too old to apply again, so he rose between 4 and 5 am each day to study mathematics, German, and French with the assistance of his wife. He later qualified as an interpreter in French. He just missed a place, but was given a nominated place on the recommendation of [[George White (British Army officer)|Sir George White]] ([[Commander-in-Chief, India]]). In 1897, accompanied by his wife and baby son, he became the first former ranker to go there.Bonham-Carter 1963, p.39-40 Under [[George Francis Robert Henderson|George Henderson]] he absorbed the principles, derived from [[Antoine-Henri Jomini|Jomini]], [[Carl von Clausewitz|Clausewitz]], and [[Edward Bruce Hamley|Edward Hamley]]'s ''Operations of War'' (1866), of concentration of physical and moral force and the destruction of the main enemy army. He passed out second from Staff College in December 1898Heathcote, p. 251 and was then seconded for service in the Intelligence Department at the War Office on 1 April 1899.{{London Gazette|issue=27083|page=3337|date=26 May 1899 |nolink=y}} As a staff captain he was the junior of two officers in the Colonial (later renamed Imperial) section.Woodward, 1998, p3 ==Boer War and War Office== With the start of the [[Second Boer War]], Robertson was appointed as Deputy Assistant Adjutant-General to [[Frederick Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts]], the British [[Commander-in-Chief]] South Africa, on 15 January 1900.{{London Gazette|issue=27167|page=1173|date=20 February 1900 |nolink=y}} He was present at the [[Battle of Paardeberg]] (17–26 February 1900), the [[Battle of Poplar Grove]] (7 March 1900) and other battles in March and May.Heathcote, p. 251 Robertson was promoted to [[major]] on 10 March 1900{{London Gazette|issue=27179|page=2196|date=3 April 1900 |nolink=y}} and was [[mentioned in despatches]] on 2 April 1901.{{London Gazette|issue=27305|page=2605|date=16 April 1901 |nolink=y}} He returned to the War Office in October 1900 and on 29 November 1900 was promoted [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Lieutenant-colonel (British Army)|lieutenant-colonel]] for his services in [[South Africa]].Heathcote, p. 251{{London Gazette |issue=27359 |date=27 September 1901 |page=6303 |nolink=y}} On 1 October 1901 he was appointed Assistant Quartermaster-General with specific responsibility for the Foreign Military Intelligence section, on the recommendation of the Intelligence expert General Sir [[Henry Brackenbury]],{{London Gazette|issue=27456|page=4673|date=22 July 1902 |nolink=y}} and worked closely with [[William Nicholson, 1st Baron Nicholson|William Nicholson]] (then Director of Military Operations).Heathcote, p. 251 Although Robertson was later to be a staunch advocate of Britain's concentration of effort on the Western Front, in March 1902 (before the ''[[Entente Cordiale]]'') he wrote a paper ("Treaty Obligations of the British Empire") recommending that, in the event of Belgian neutrality being violated by France or Germany in any future war, Britain should concentrate on naval warfare and deploy no more troops to Belgium than was needed to "afford ocular [visible] proof of our share in the war."
